body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: A Bath Beach man died in what appears to have been an electrical fire in his home yesterday, fire officials and the police said. The fire began about 6 a.m. at 69 Bay 29 Street, where rescuers found a man identified as Andrew Levy, 40, dead in his apartment. Two other family members were taken to Victory Memorial Hospital and were reported in
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies In A House Fire

body: Amid the bad news about the subway system -- fires, delays and deferred dreams like the Second Avenue subway -- one ambitious project, the spectacular European-style train terminal at Coney Island, reaches a milestone this weekend. At 12:41 a.m. tomorrow, an N train will roll into the new station, at Stillwell and Surf Avenues, completing the
title: And Now for the Good News From the Subway System; New Terminal in Coney Island Rivals the Great Train Sheds of Europe

body: An article on Saturday about a hit-and-run accident in Brooklyn that killed an 85-year-old Russian physicist misidentified the neighborhood where it occurred. It was Bath Beach, not Coney Island.
title: Corrections

body: An 85-year-old Russian-born physicist was killed by a hit-and-run driver yesterday during his early-morning jog in Coney Island, the police said. The physicist, Ilya Aptekar, was crossing Cropsey Avenue at Bay Parkway about 5:20 a.m., witnesses told the police, when he was struck by a westbound car. Witnesses described the car as a large
title: Brooklyn Physicist, 85, Is Killed in a Hit-and-Run Accident

body: Three Roman Catholic elementary schools in Brooklyn and Queens that had been scheduled for closing received joyous news yesterday as they began their Easter vacations: the Brooklyn Diocese approved emergency business plans drawn up by the pupils' parents and agreed to keep the schools open as long as they meet the plans' goals. The three schools --
title: Three Schools in the Brooklyn Diocese Are Given Reprieves

body: To the Editor: I read ''Once Mighty, Catholic Schools Find Status Is Diminished'' (news article, Feb. 13) with a mixture of sadness and nostalgia. From 1973 to 1982, I taught happily in one of the schools in the Brooklyn Diocese that is slated to close in June: St. Finbar in Bath Beach. Catholics have a tradition and creative giftedness in
title: A Sad Time For Catholic Schools

body: A 74-year-old man was severely burned yesterday in an early-morning fire in his basement apartment in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn, a Fire Department spokesman said. The man, whose name was not released by the authorities, was pulled from the apartment at 128 Bay 50th Street by Capt. Christopher Joyce of Engine Company 318, and taken to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Burned In Basement Fire

body: The Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn and Queens moved yesterday to take financial control of the diocese's struggling elementary schools from the pastors and principals who have run them for more than a century and to install lay boards to steer the schools' finances instead. The measure proposed by the bishop, Nicholas A. DiMarzio, came the day
title: Church Plans For Boards, Not Pastors, To Run Schools

body: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced the biggest round of school closings in the history of the city's Catholic education system yesterday, citing plummeting enrollment, escalating costs and the shifting demographics of neighborhoods across Brooklyn and Queens. Twenty-two Catholic elementary schools in the two boroughs, with a total
title: Brooklyn Diocese Closing 22 Schools As Enrollment Falls
